all_paragraphs: In the wake of the Coronavirus outbreak, many data sources have been made available to the public in an effort to encourage research in the field. Recently, the White House and a group of leading researchers published the COVID-19 Open Research Dataset (CORD-19), which is available on Kaggle. The goal is for the global research community to apply recent advances in machine learning and natural language processing to generate insights into the infectious disease.
As is true of most text mining efforts, generating summary statistics and visually representing the content of text information is a very important part of exploratory data analysis.

In this post, we will perform exploratory data analysis on the COVID-19 Open Research Dataset (CORD-19). We will use python libraries such as ‘seaborn’, ‘matplotlib’ and Pandas to explore and visualize the categorical and text information provided in the data set. The specific file we will be using is called “all_sources_metadata_2020–03–13.csv”.

Next, let’s print the first five rows of data. Let’s also relax the limit on the number of columns displayed (the output is suppressed here):
There are many places we can start with our analysis. The easiest first step would be to look at the list of columns and its length:
We can also look at the number of rows in the data set:
Next, we can look at the frequency in journals across all publications. We can use the Counter method from the collections module to achieve this (output is suppressed here as well):
We can see that this is quite the list of journal names and frequencies. We can narrow this down by removing the missing values (‘nan’) and limiting our output to the most common 10 journals:
We can then visualize the most common journal publications using ‘matplotlib’ and ‘seaborn’. Let’s do so for the five most common publications:
It is also worth noting that if we look at the total number of journals:
there are 1732 journals in this data set.

Just out of curiosity, I looked up the impact factors for each of these journals. For those who don’t know, journal impact factor is an index that measures how frequently a journal is cited. The more prestigious or harder to publish in journals typically have higher impact factors. The most common five journals had the following impact factors in 2019:

Since Emerging Infectious Disease (Emerg Infect Dis) has the highest impact factor and the second highest number of publications, it may be interesting to analyze the text content of papers published in this journal.

Another interesting project would be to find the impact factor of each journal and augment the existing data with impact factor information. Augmenting our data with this information would allow us to filter and search for high impact COVID-19 research publications. In order to find the journal with the highest impact factor and relative number of publications, we’d need to map 1732 journals to impact factor values.

For now, let’s assume that Emerging Infectious Disease is a good journal with a large number of publications related to COVID-19. Reinforcing this assumption, SJR, a journal ranking website, ranked Emerging Infectious Disease 8th on their list of infectious disease journals, which is pretty good.
Moving on, let’s filter our data to include only data from Emerging Infectious Disease and print the data frame length for verification:
And we see that the data frame length is 941.
Now let’s look at some abstracts. Let’s look at the first 5 abstracts just to get an idea of the content in the text:
The next thing we could look at is the sentiment scores of the abstracts. Maybe we can assign sentiment scores to each abstract and see if the score are associated with positive results.
In order to get sentiment scores, we need to import a python package called textblob. The documentation for textblob can be found here. In order to install textblob open a command line and type:
We will use the polarity score as our measure for positive or negative sentiment. The polarity score is a float with values from -1 to +1.
For example, let’s consider the 1991 publication on the cancer drug taxol, Taxol: a new and effective anti-cancer drug. The abstract has a postive sentiment sentence:
“Clinical trials indicate that taxol is effective in the treatment of patients with refractory ovarian cancer, breast cancer, malignant melanoma and probably other solid tumors.”

“Clinical trials indicate that taxol is ineffective in the treatment of patients with refractory ovarian cancer, breast cancer, malignant melanoma and probably other solid tumors.”
and pass that into our textblob object we have:
We see that textblob is capable of capturing negative and positive sentiment in scientific statements. Let’s apply this to the abstracts in our COVID-19 data:
Let’s also limit the columns in our data frame to include ‘abstract’ and ‘sentiment’ and print the first five rows:
We can also count the number of positive and negative sentiments:
Just to be safe, let’s increase the polarity threshold to >0.5 for positive sentiment and print a few positive sentiment abstracts:
We see that textblob does a decent job assigning positive scores to abstracts. Let’s do the same for the negative sentiment abstracts, where we will decrease the negative sentiment threshold to -0.1:
These results are less conclusive. Ideally, we’d want abstracts with negative sentiment to contain statements like the following:
“ There was no evidence of horizontal transmission to other cats because only 2 cats developed antibodies against H5N1 virus.”
It would be interesting to apply this sentiment score method across all journals and compare negative and positive sentiment between journals.

I’ll stop here but please feel free to continue the exploration process with this data. It may be worth looking into other text classification methods like BERT which may be used to classify journals reporting negative and positive results.

To summarize, in this post we performed a simple exploratory analysis of the COVID-19 Open Research Dataset (CORD-19). We generated frequency counts for the number of journals, visualized the most common journals, filtered our data to restrict our analysis to a high impact journal with a large number of publications, and performed sentiment analysis on the journal abstracts. I hope you found this post useful/interesting. The code in this post is available on GitHub. Thank you for reading!
